metadata.title: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
anatomical location body part affected: Affects both upper and lower motor neurons;(1) eventually multisystem impairment develops
description: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) defined –ALS is a progressive neurodegenerative disease of upper and lower motor neurons(1,10) –The name derives from muscular wasting (“amyotrophy”), the region of the spinal cord primarily affected (the lateral cord, which contains descending motor pathways responsible for voluntary limb movement), and the degenerative changes that occur in the nerve fiber tissue (“sclerosis”)(2)

Types of ALS –Sporadic -Approximately 90–95%  of persons with ALS in the United States have sporadic ALS(2) –Familial -Approximately 5–10%  of persons with ALS in the United States have familial ALS(2) -Autosomal dominant or autosomal recessive disease that is clinically similar to sporadic ALS(10) -Is probably a distinct entity from sporadic ALS, pathologically and biochemically(10) -Genetic mutations(1,17) -Individuals with mutations affecting the SOD1 gene have a decrease in copper-zinc superoxide dismutase (SOD) enzyme activity, which may result in increased free radicals and lead to increased neurotoxicity(4,17) -C9ORF72  mutation – reported in up to 23% of persons with familial ALS and 4% of those with sporadic ALS(17) -TAR DNA binding protein mutations and FUS mutations have been associated with ALS and frontotemporal dementia(17) -ANG – encodes angiogenin, ribonuclease (RNase A family)(17)

Incidence –In Europe and North America, ALS is diagnosed in 1.47 to 2.7 per 100,000 persons each year(10) –In the United States, 5,600 new cases are diagnosed each year (2 cases per 100,000)(10) –It is estimated that 30,000 Americans have the disease(10) –Typical commencement of symptoms is in sixth to seventh decade of life(1)

ICD-10 codes.G12.2: motor neuron disease (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: Because there is evidence that military service is a risk factor for development of ALS, in 2008 ALS became a presumptively compensable illness for all veterans with 90 days or more of continuously active service in the United States military(11)
Regulations for financing assistive technology devices (ATDs) are complex and might influence adequate provision of and training on these devices for persons who need multiple ATDs(11)
presentation signs and symptoms: General –Pattern and progression of ALS vary(2) –Onset typically is insidious -The onset is often so subtle that the symptoms are overlooked, preventing early detection –ALS can be subdivided based on which symptoms present first -Spinal-onset  ALS -Approximately two-thirds  of ALS patients have onset in the extremities first(32) -Bulbar-onset  ALS -Approximately 30% of patients with ALS have onset of symptoms beginning in bulbar functions (swallowing, chewing, speaking, and breathing)(31) –Progressive muscle weakness in extremities(2) -Progression of weakness generally is distal to proximal(4) –Progressive weakness in the muscles involved in respiration, swallowing, and speech formation(2) –Progressive muscle atrophy(2) –Pseudobulbar affect (episodes of involuntary or uncontrolled laughing and/or crying) may be seen(17) –Diagnostic criteria require that both upper motor neurons (UMNs) and lower motor neurons (LMNs) are involved -Both UMN and LMN lesions can result in decreased strength and atrophy -Where UMNs are involved, spasticity and hyperreflexia are present -Where LMNs are affected, findings include hyporeflexia and hypotonicity(4) -A combination of UMN and LMN symptoms will occur, resulting in varying signs and symptoms(4) –Muscle fasciculations are a frequent finding indicating LMN involvement(4) -Brief, involuntary contractions affecting a small number of muscle fibers are visible under the skin –Cognitive impairment can occur(4) -Cognitive impairment manifests particularly as executive dysfunction, apathy, disinhibition, and social cognition deficits

Early symptoms –Spinal-onset  ALS -Symptoms typically begin in the hands and feet(4) -Patient may report tripping, items falling out of his/her hands, or difficulty with ADLs(2) -Fatigue(2) -Foot drop(4) -Cramping of muscles; particularly in the feet and hands(2) -Decreased function in upper and lower extremities(2) -Decreased strength in neck extensor musculature; patient may complain of fatigue after reading(4) -Shortness of breath on exertion(4) -The patient has difficulty sleeping in supine due to breathing problems(4)  –Bulbar-onset  ALS -Symptoms start by affecting bulbar functions (swallowing, chewing, speaking, and breathing)(33) -The patient may have difficulty repositioning tongue, realigning lips, or opening and closing mouth(4) -Dysarthria -Dysphagia -Patient has trouble projecting voice(2) -Sialorrhea – excessive saliva causing drooling(4)

Advanced symptoms –Unable to extend neck; head drop or droop(4) –Paralysis of voluntary muscles(2) -Dependent edema due to absence of pumping action of voluntary muscle contractions –Contractures(4) –Pain related to contractures and immobility –Joint subluxations(4) –Cognitive impairment(4) –Respiratory compromise -Shortness of breath at rest(4) -Labored breathing(4) -Mechanical ventilation eventually is required(2) –Inability to speak due to dysarthria(4) and/or respiratory constraints –Difficulty swallowing/inability to swallow(4) –Please see  Clinical Review…Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS): Communication Disorders  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708852;  Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708986; and  Clinical Review…Augmentative and Alternative Communication: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709142 for more detailed information on these topics Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Patients with ALS are at risk for falls. Follow facility protocols for fall prevention
Allow frequent rests during examination, as indicated. Depending on stage of disease, sections of assessment may be deferred

causes: Possible causes being studied include the following:–Excessive glutamate, which can destroy some neurons, has been found in ALS patients’ serum and cerebrospinal fluids(4)–Autoimmune response leading to death of nerve cells(4)–Environmental factors such as exposure to toxic or infectious agents, physical trauma, and behavioral and occupationalfactors(12)–In the case of SOD1  gene mutation, free radicals build up, causing cell destruction(4)
pathogenesis: UMN and LMN degeneration occurs. The spinal cord atrophies, with ventral nerve root thinning and loss of largemyelinated fibers within the motor nerves. This causes progressive muscle weakness of the skeletal and smooth muscles,muscle atrophy, and loss of function related to movement, speech, swallowing, and breathing(10)

Multiple components of pathogenesis have been found(32)–Genetic factors–Oxidative stress–Mitochondrial dysfunction–Impaired axonal transport–Neurofilament aggregation–Protein aggregation–Inflammatory dysfunction and contribution of non-neuronal  cells–Deficits in neurotrophic factors and dysfunction of signaling pathways–Glutamate excitotoxicity-Elevated levels of glutamate have been found in serum and cerebrospinal fluid in cases of sporadic ALS(10)

Genetics–ALS can be passed on directly or indirectly (skipping a generation) in familial ALS(10)–There are at least 18 different genetic mutations that have been associated with ALS(10)–Familial ALS can be either autosomal dominant or autosomal recessive(10)
risk factors: Sporadic ALS is more likely to be diagnosed in males than females(10)
Possible risk factors–Lead ingestion(3)–Exposure to agricultural chemicals(32)–Military service(32)–Exposure to neurotoxins (e.g., BMAA)(17)

overall contraindications precautions: Complications can include: aspiration pneumonia pulmonary embolism nutritional deficiency skin complications from being wheelchair-  or bed-bound
Limited mobility and confinement to wheelchair put patients at risk for deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
Exercise Precautions include the following: –Allow frequent rests as needed; monitor closely for fatigue –Avoid heavy eccentric loads(4)

Aspiration Dysphagia is common in patients with ALS and places patients at risk for aspiration(17) –Food consistency may need to be modified –Patient education on swallowing techniques may be needed –Ultimately a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube often is required due to persistent choking –Refer to speech pathologist as indicated for swallowing issues
Be aware of advanced directives Patient may have a “do not resuscitate” (DNR) or a “do not intubate”(DNI) order
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: Patients with ALS are at risk for falls. Follow facility protocols for fall prevention
Allow frequent rests during examination, as indicated. Depending on stage of disease, sections of assessment may be deferred

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Etiology of illness -When was ALS diagnosed in the patient? -What is the reason for referral?

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management Document the progression of the disease to date How has it been treated? Who is the patient’s medical team composed of? Any recent hospital stays? Any complications? Medical management may include insertion of PEG tube, treatment of respiratory dysfunction, prescription of orthotic and assistive devices, and symptomatic treatment Supportive care may be necessary for complications such as aspiration and respiratory failure. Tracheostomy and mechanical ventilation may be required
course of treatment.medications: Medications for current illness/injury Determine what medications clinician has prescribed Riluzole was the first medication approved by the U.S. FDA for treatment of ALS (in 1995)(12) Glutamate antagonist Has been shown to extend tracheostomy-free  survival(17)(17) baclofen or tizanidine for spasticity NSAIDs or tramadol (Ultram) for pain relief glycopyrrolate, amitriptyline, or botulinum toxin for sialorrhea Evidence for the effectiveness of symptomatic treatment is limited Based on a 2017 summary of 9 Cochrane systematic reviews of symptomatic treatments(18)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnosis is made based on the existence of both UMN and LMN symptoms with advancement of symptoms over the course of a year(1,10)
Authors of a systematic review conducted in 2018 concluded that the Awaji-Shima  criteria, a form of EMG testing, is the most sensitive criteria used for diagnosing ALS(26)
Diagnostic criteria for ALS were established by the World Federation of Neurology Research Group on Motor Neuron Diseases in 1998.(4) A diagnosis of ALS requires:(10)
The presence of evidence of LMN degeneration by clinical, electrophysiological, or neuropathological examination
The presence of evidence of UMN degeneration by clinical examination
The absence of electrophysiological and pathological evidence of other diseases associated with UMN or LMN degeneration
Levels of glutamate in serum and CSF may be elevated
MRI is often done to exclude other diagnoses
MRI usually is normal in ALS, but increased signal in the corticospinal tracts may occur
EMG and nerve conduction studies may show evidence of ongoing degeneration
Videofluoroscopic and/or fiberoptic evaluation of swallowing may be performed

Home remedies/complementary therapies : Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or complementary therapies (e.g., acupuncture),what they are used for, and whether they help. Some patients may be on a
ketogenic diet (highcalorie,  high carbohydrate diet)in an attempt to slow the progression of the disease and extend their life
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful. What education has the patient received about the condition?

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Identify aggravating and easing factors for each symptom -Fatigue -Fatigue may be aggravated by overexertion, sleep disruption, pain, poor nutrition, respiratory compromise, stress, weather (too hot or too cold), and certain medications -Factors that may ease fatigue symptoms include rest periods and energy-conserving  techniques -Cramping -Aggravating factors may include cold weather and decreased circulation caused by immobility -Pain -Aggravating factors may include position, depression, and insufficient rest; easing factors may include position changes/ROM exercise
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). See  Presentation/signs and symptoms , above
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much); use a nonverbal scale as appropriate
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to external variables. As disease progresses, pain may develop from increased dependency and muscle disuse
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Sleep disturbance -Document sleep problems and number of wakings/night, if any -Less restful sleep due to poor diaphragm function, which causes loss of REM sleep -Sustained awakenings due to hypoventilation accompanied by rapid shallow breathing -It is important to determine whether the cause of sleeping difficulties is ventilatory failure -Patients may be referred for overnight polysomnography. In some cases sleep can be improved by using noninvasive ventilatory (NIV) support -Sleep-disordered  breathing occurs at a higher frequency in persons with ALS compared to the general population, due to early involvement of respiratory muscles(19) -Significantly impacts quality of life and survival and may predict prognosis -Sleep-disordered  breathing usually precedes daytime respiratory symptoms and chronic respiratory failure -Early identification and management of sleep-disordered  breathing are crucial -Managing sleep-disordered  breathing with noninvasive ventilation improves quality of life and survival
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (dizziness, headache, cognitive impairment, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Respiratory status -Any respiration supports presently? -Inquire about existence of underlying pulmonary disease that predated diagnosis of ALS (e.g., asthma, chronic bronchitis) -Past or current smoking -Occupational exposure to pulmonary irritants -Current respiratory medications -Document oxygen saturation levels and respiratory rate during evaluation/treatment -Obtain pulmonary function test results where available Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _______________________

past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Inquire about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Vocation/avocation and associated repetitive behaviors, if any -Is patient working? -Does patient wish to continue working? -What are the patient’s leisure activities? -Is a home/office assessment indicated? -An evaluation of necessary supports for augmenting employment may be indicated pending patient requests
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Functional limitations/assistance with ADLs/adaptive equipment -What supports does patient have in place to date? -What are the barriers to the patient’s mobility and functions? Can modifications assist the patient in his or her desired tasks?
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives (e.g., caregivers, children). Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary? -Authors of a scoping review of the supportive care needs of patients with ALS and their caregivers found a significant need for more practical, social, informational, psychological, emotional, and spiritual support(20)

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting.)  Evaluation procedures should be modified according to patient presentation. Key evaluation findings in patients with ALS are listed below; otherwise, standard assessment techniques should be utilized
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assistive and adaptive devices –Provision of assistive technology devices may be crucial for functional independence, maintenance of physical and mental health, and self-care(11) –What devices are currently in use? Are they appropriate? (It is not uncommon for patient needs to change in a matter of weeks) –Assess need for ankle-foot  orthoses (AFOs), knee-ankle-foot  orthoses (KAFOs), and ambulatory assistive devices –Wheelchairs for ALS patients often are custom-designed  with features unique to those with ALS. These may include alternative driving systems, ventilator trays, and elevating and tilting features(11) -Programs to reuse these chairs for other individuals with ALS reduce costs and time required to get a chair(11) –Ensure that patient has appropriate pressure-relieving  equipment for bed and wheelchair -Mobile manipulators (e.g., teleoperated manipulators to retrieve objects)(13) -Brain-computer  interfaces(14) -Mechanical lifts
relevant tests and measures.balance: Balance –Evaluate static and dynamic balance reactions with eyes opened and closed, in sitting and/or standing as appropriate –The Berg Balance Scale or the Tinetti Balance Test can be used in the earlier stages of ALS(4)
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Evaluate vital signs during rest and with activity. The Borg Rating of Perceived Exertion (RPE) Scale can be used to assist with assessment
Does the patient use energy-conservation  techniques?

Depending on stage of disease and reason for referral, a respiratory system assessment may be indicated -Auscultation -Observation of breathing pattern and use of accessory muscles  -Assessment of cough
The 6-minute  walk for distance test (6MWT) or 2-minute  walk for distance test (2MWT) can be used to assess endurance
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Palpate pulses and compare Functional mobility  (including transfers, etc.) –Evaluate transfer status and need for assistive devices –Utilize the FIM as indicated –The physical functioning subscale (PF10) of the Medical Outcomes Study Short Form–36  (SF-36)  can be used for quantifying physical functioning in patients with ALS(5) -Researchers in the Netherlands conducted a study to investigate unidimensionality and differential item functioning of the SF-36  PF10 in patients with various neurological disorders. One hundred ninety-eight patients post-stroke,  151 with multiple sclerosis and 193 with ALS, participated in the study -Analysis demonstrated that the sum score could be utilized as an indicator of overall physical performance in all diagnoses; there was only one item (number 10) in the subscale for patients with ALS that did not fall in line with results anticipated. The authors suggested this may have occurred because the item called for the assessment of two different skills
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Gait/locomotion –Evaluate gait or wheelchair mobility –Assess for foot drop and any other abnormal patterns during gait -In order to compensate for foot drop, patients often excessively flex at their hips or knees –Assess need for assistive device or wheelchair –Gait speed can be assessed using the 10-meter  walk test (10MWT) –The Dynamic Gait Index (DGI) can be used to assess safety during ambulation Motor function (motor control/tone/learning) –Assess tone using Modified Ashworth Scale -Note presence of muscle spasms –Assess coordination -Note loss of dexterity in absence of weakness -Jebsen-Taylor  Hand Function Test or 9-Hole  Peg Test (9-HPT)  may be used to assess fine motor coordination
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Muscle strength –Manual muscle test (MMT) upper and lower extremities as indicated where tone or coordination abnormalities are not present –Handheld dynamometry or isokinetic strength testing as indicated(4)
observation inspection palpation includi: Especially important for patients with increased dependency; are there open areas or pressure ulcers? -Stage and measure any areas noted -Does the patient have appropriate pressure-relieving  cushions/mattress?
relevant tests and measures.posture: Posture –Evaluate overall posture –Evaluate posture in wheelchair seating system as indicated –Does the patient present with “head drop”? –Patients with axial truncal weakness have difficulty attaining and maintaining erect posture -To assist in attaining a standing position, they may support their torso by “walking” their hands up their thighs
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Range of motion –Evaluate active and passive ROM and flexibility
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Reflex testing –Evaluate deep tendon and abnormal reflexes –Hyperreflexia typically coexists with weak and atrophied muscles, due to presence of both UMN and LMN impairment(17) –Presence of positive Babinski test and clonus indicate UMN pathology(32) Self-care/activities  of daily living  (objective testing)  –Observe or inquire about ADLs –Barthel Index may be used
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –The Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis Assessment Questionnaire comprising 40 items (ALSAQ-40)  and the Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis Assessment Questionnaire comprising 5 items (ALSAQ-5)  may be simplified in the form of a sum score that can used as a marker of global health status(6) –ALS Severity Scale (ALS-SS)(7,8)speech, swallowing, lower extremity function, and upper extremity function -Categories are scored from 1to 10; 10 is normal -Total sum score spans 4–40  points –ALS Functional Rating Scale (ALS-FRS)(7) -Ten items on test -Each item can be scored from level 0 to 4 -Zero is unable and 4 is normal -Best score is 40 points
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Screen for cognitive impairment using the Mini-Mental  State Examination (MMSE) or other cognitive assessment tool. Where available, obtain results of neuropsychological testing performed by other disciplines

contraindications precautions: Allow frequent rests as needed; monitor closely for fatigue
The clinician should avoid placing heavy eccentric loads on the patient(4)
other: Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary presented below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Diagnosis/need for treatment ALS management focuses on multidisciplinary symptomatic treatment and palliative care(12) Impaired strength, balance, ROM, coordination, mobility, and ADLs Rule out  (There are many conditions that must be ruled out prior to confirming a diagnosis of ALS; below is a partial list. Patients with ALS ultimately will have both  UMN and LMN symptoms)(10) Myasthenia gravis Polyradiculopathies Multifocal motor neuropathy Kennedy’s disease or bulbospinal muscular atrophy Spinal muscular atrophy Primary lateral sclerosis CNS tumor Cervical spondylotic myelopathy CNS radiation injury Multiple sclerosis Syphilis Diffuse Lewy body disease Syringomyelia Spinal cord tumor Myelopathy plus radiculopathy Lyme disease
prognosis: There is no cure for ALS(10)
ALS is unremittingly progressive and typically results in death within 2–5 years of diagnosis(10)  –Fifty percent live for > 3 years, 25% live for > 5 years, and 10% live for > 10 years
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Counseling for assistance coping with functional decline and a terminal illness(8) Speech-language  pathologist (SLP) Respirologist, respiratory nurse specialist, or respiratory therapist to assist with ventilation strategies as disease progresses Occupational therapy for ADL training Support groups
other considerations: Caregiver burden –Authors of a 2018 systematic review found that informal caregivers of patients with ALS experience caregiver burden that increases as the disease progresses(21) -A total of 25 studies that investigated quantitative relations between patient or caregiver factors and caregiver burden were included in the review -There was high-quality  evidence for a relationship between caregiver burden and behavioral impairments of the patient -Higher caregiver burden was also associated with greater physical impairment of the patient and more depressive feelings of the caregiver -The need to identify caregivers at risk for caregiver burden and to develop interventions to decrease caregiver burden was identified

Airway clearance techniques –Researchers in the United States found that total medical costs, hospitalizations, and pneumonia claims were less after than before initiation of high-frequency  chest wall oscillation (HFCWO) in a group of patients with neuromuscular disease(22) -A total of 426 patients were included. Thirty-seven  percent had motor neuron disease -These findings lend support to the routine use of HFCWO in the care of patients with neuromuscular diseases –Researchers in Brazil concluded that noninvasive ventilation improved chest wall tidal volume, end-inspiratory  volume, and end-expiratory  volume as well as minute ventilation(15) -Based on a case series that involved 9 patients with ALS -Optoelectronic plethysmography was used to examine breathing pattern changes in ALS. Modifications in breathing patterns were observed even in early-stage  patients

Telehealth may be incorporated for the management and treatment of patients who are experiencing lower physical and respiratory function and those who have difficulty accessing a clinic. Synchronous videoconferencing is the optimal method for providing telehealth services(28)

Utilizing a structured home-based  exercise program without supervision of a physical therapist may also be feasible to alleviate functional deterioration in patients in early stages of ALS(29) –The structured exercise program consisted of strengthening and stretching exercises for both the upper and lower extremities as well as functional training for ADLs such as sit to stand. Body weight in anti-gravity  positions was used for primary resistance. Frequency and duration were individually set for each patient depending on their physical capabilities
treatment summary: Goals/treatment will vary depending on disease progression and patient wishes

Therapeutic exercises –Authors of a 2020 systematic review and meta-analysis  found support for the benefits of exercise therapy for patients with ALS, including significant improvements in functional ability as well as pulmonary function(27) -Based on 7 RCT studies of 322 patients with ALS that met inclusion criteria -The researchers found that moderate-intensity  exercise can improve muscle strength and oxygen consumption -Exercise may also slow the rate of motor neuron degeneration, minimize stress on fast-twitch  muscle fibers, reduce spasticity levels, and improve musculoskeletal endurance and cardiopulmonary function –Guidelines from the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) state that an exercise program for persons with motor neuron disease should be considered to maintain joint ROM, prevent contractures, reduce stiffness and discomfort, and optimize function and quality of life(23) -The program should be appropriate to the person's level of function and tailored to his or her needs, abilities, and preferences, taking into account factors such as postural needs and fatigue  -It is advised to check whether family members/caregivers are able and willing to help with exercise programs –Researchers in the United States evaluated the safety and tolerability of resistance and endurance exercise in patients with ALS in an RCT. Participants were randomized to resistance, endurance, or stretching/ROM exercises. After 24 weeks all 3 exercise regimens were found to be safe, with no differences in disease progression between groups(24)

Respiratory training –Authors of a 2016 systematic review and meta-analysis  concluded that respiratory muscle training in ALS can be used as an adjunctive therapy to improve ventilatory function and respiratory strength(16) -The review included 9 RCTs with a total of 194 patients who had either MS or ALS -Respiratory muscle training resulted in improvements in respiratory muscle strength (maximum expiratory pressure/ maximum inspiratory pressure) and forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1) compared to the control group, but the groups did not differ in forced vital capacity or distance walked in 6MWT –Expiratory muscle strength training (EMST) utilizing a handheld, one-way spring-loaded  valve trainer can improve maximum expiratory pressure (MEP) in patients with ALS(30) -Forty-eight  patients with ALSwere randomized to the EMST group or sham group -The EMST group performed expiratory training at home 5 days a week using a handheld one-way  spring-loaded  valve trainer. EMST was performed with the device set to50% of the patient’s MEP. A nose clip was applied in order to prevent air escaping from the nostrils due to nasopharyngeal weakness. Patients were asked to take a deep breath, hold their cheeks lightly, and blow forcefully into the training device for 25 expirations (5 set of 5 repetitions) -Those in the sham group received a sham device that looked similar, but with the internal spring system removed -Results show that the end of the 8-week  study, MEP was significantly improved for those in the EMST group

Treatment of fatigue –Authors of a 2018 Cochrane systematic review of treatment of fatigue in ALS found that there are few randomized studies and the quality of the evidence is very low(25) -One pharmacological study and 3 non-pharmacological  studies (resistance exercise, respiratory exercise, and repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation [rTMS]), involving a total of 86 participants, were included -Authors found no clear improvements in fatigue for resistance exercise versus usual care and very low-quality  evidence suggesting possible improvements in fatigue for modafinil treatment versus placebo, respiratory exercise versus a sham intervention, and rTMS versus sham rTMS . maintenance or prevention: Home exercise program for ROM, pressure-relieving  strategies, and therapeutic activities as indicated

Patients are advised to obtain equipment and assistive devices before they need them, if possible Due to the rapid progression of the disease, the addition of assistive technologies is essential so that the patient’s ability to participate in normal daily activities is not unduly restricted(11)

Ensure that home environment is safe by eliminating tripping hazards and installing sturdy grab bars/railings at strategic locations. Shield sharp corners on furniture and place a shower chair in the bathroom
When possible, a mechanical lift should be used to avoid injury when lifting a patient who has fallen
Genetic counseling is advised if there is a family history of ALS(10)
